questions.text: Early visual rehabilitation is seen in which of the following cataract surgery:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phacoemulsification Modern extracapsular cataract extraction surgery involves the removal of the lens fibers, which form the nucleus and cortex of the cataract, leaving the posterior epithelial capsule to hold the new artificial intraocular lens (IOL) and keep the vitreous humor away from the anterior chamber. Extracapsular techniques of cataract extraction surgery originally involved manual nuclear expression. Phacoemulsification is a mechanically assisted extracapsular technique of cataract extraction surgery.

Highyeild:

Merits of phacoemulsification over manual SICS Topical anesthesia may be sufficient for phacoemulsification in expert hands. Post-operative congestion is minimal after phacoemulsification, as phaco is usually performed through a clear corneal incision. Small incision - The chief advantage of phacoemulsification over manual SICS is that it can be performed through a smaller (3.2 mm) incision. Less corneal complications - Phacoemulsification can be performed in the posterior chamber without prolapsing the nucleus into the anterior chamber, thereby minimizing the risk of corneal complications. Visual rehabilitation is comparatively quicker in phacoemulsification as compared to manual SICS. Post-operative astigmatism is comparatively less when foldable IOLs are implanted through a smaller incision (3.2 mm).

Extraedge:

Demerits of phacoemulsification vis-a-vis manual SICS Learning curve for phacoemulsification is more painful both for the surgeons and patients. Complications encountered during phacoemulsification like nuclear drops are Machine dependent - This procedure is solely machine-dependent and in the event of an unfortunate machine failure in the middle of surgery, one has to shift to conventional ECCE. High cost. Limitations - It is very difficult to deal with hard cataracts (grade IV and V) with this technique, and also there is a high risk of serious corneal complications due to more use of phaco energy in such cases.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important factor in the prevention of the endophthalmitis in cataract surgery?

options.label: B
options.text: One week of antibiotic therapy prior to surgery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Preoperative preparation with povidone-iodine Postoperative endophthalmitis is a very devastating complication and every step should be taken to reduce its occurrence. Unattended air conditioning filter systems are often the culprits and regular maintenance of the filters is of paramount importance.

Highyeild:

Risk Factors of Endophthalmitis : Doctor -Hand Cleaning, proper draping Patient -Immunocompromised, old age, comorbidities, local infections Environment - Surgery related: Leaky wounds, Heparinization, surgical complications.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: C . Shedders of pathogenic organisms amongst the theater personnel should be identified by regular screening and should be promptly treated. Options: A and D .In addition to the use of Povidone iodine 5% solution in the conjunctival sac a few minutes prior to surgery, proper construction of the wound, injectable intraocular lenses, use of prophylactic intracameral antibiotics or prophylactic subconjunctival antibiotic injection at the conclusion of cataract surgery, placing a patch after the surgery for at least 4 h and initiating topical antibiotics from the same day of surgery helps to lower the frequency of postoperative endophthalmitis.

Extraedge:

Diagnosis of Endophthalmitis - It is a clinical diagnosis confirmed with positive aqueous or vitreous culture.

questions.text: A 25-year-old executive presents with metamorphopsia in his right eye. On examination, the fundus shows a shallow detachment at the macula. The fluorescein angiography shows a “smokestack” sign. Which of the following management should be given?

options.label: B
options.text: Systemic corticosteroid for two weeks and then taper

options.label: C
options.text: Pulse methylprednisolone for three days and then taper

options.label: D
options.text: Just wait and watch for spontaneous recovery

questions.correct_answer: D. Just wait and watch for spontaneous recovery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Just wait and watch for spontaneous recovery Central serous retinopathy is a medical condition where fluid builds up behind the retina in the eye. It can cause sudden or gradual vision loss as the central retina detaches.

Highyeild:

Chief Complaints of Central Serous Retinopathy - Unilateral blurred vision with a relative scotoma in the central visual field. Unilateral metamorphopsia and/or micropsia. Patients with extrafoveal involvement may be asymptomatic. Visual Acuity - VA ranges from 6/5 to 6/60, usually 6/9- 6/12.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Topical antibiotic – corticosteroid combination - this is not the correct option. Option: B. Systemic corticosteroid for two weeks and then taper - this is not the preferred option. Option: C. Pulse methylprednisolone for three days and then taper - this is an incorrect option

Extraedge:

Diagnosis of CSE Distance & Near visual acuity testing Retinoscopy Amsler Grid photo stress test/Dazzling/Re-adaptation tie Ophthalmoscopy Special Investigation FFA ICG OCT

questions.text: A patient Mohan, aged 60 yrs, needs an eye examination. He needs a drug that will dilate his eyes but not paralyze his ciliary muscles. Choose the drug:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phenylephrine Phenylephrine is a selective α1-adrenergic receptor activator that results in the constriction of both arteries and veins. Severe side effects may include a slow heart rate, intestinal ischemia, chest pain, kidney failure, and tissue death at the site of injection. It is unclear if use during pregnancy or breastfeeding is safe.

Highyeild:

Phenylephrine (2.5%) is used diagnostically for fundus examination. And 10% is used therapeutically to break posterior synechiae and pupillary block . Phenylephrine is commonly used in studies of accommodative dynamics to dilate the iris because optometers normally fail to measure through small pupils.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Atropine - Atropine or atropine sulfate carries FDA indications for anti-sialagogue/anti-vagal effect, organophosphate/muscarinic poisoning, and bradycardia . Atropine acts as a competitive, reversible antagonist of muscarinic receptors: an anticholinergic drug. Option: C. Cyclopentolate - Cyclopentolate is a muscarinic antagonist. It is commonly used as an eye drop during pediatric eye examinations to dilate the eye and prevent the eye from focusing/accommodating. Option: D. Tropicamide - Tropicamide, sold under the brand name Mydriacyl among others, is a medication used to dilate the pupil and help with the examination of the eye. Specifically, it is used to help examine the back of the eye. It is applied as eye drops. Effects occur within 40 minutes and last for up to a day.

questions.text: Ocular hypotensive causing apnea in young children:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alpha 2 Agonists Brimonidine is a sympathomimetic drug MOA - it is a selective alpha 2 adrenergic agonist and lowers IOP by decreasing aqueous production and enhancing uveoscleral outflow It has an additive effect on beta blockers Dosage - it has a peak effect of 2 hrs and action lasts for 13 hrs , hence needs to be administered daily twice It is neuroprotective drugs

Highyeild:

Side effects- CNS depressant causes drowsiness, and apnea hence C/I in infants.

questions.text: What is the line of management for the Pathology depicted in the given Image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Topical Antibiotics It is an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball including the Tenon’s capsule. Etiology Panophthalmitis is an acute bacterial infection. Clinical features Symptoms include: Severe ocular pain and headache, Complete loss of vision, Profuse watering, Purulent discharge, Marked redness and swelling of the eyes, and Associated constitutional symptoms are malaise and fever. Signs Lids show marked edema and hyperemia . Eyeball is slightly proposed, ocular movements are limited and painful. Conjunctiva shows marked chemosis and ciliary as well as conjunctival congestion. Cornea is cloudy and oedematous . Anterior chamber is full of pus. Vision is completely lost and perception of light is absent. Intraocular pressure is markedly raised. Globe perforation may occur at the limbus, the pus comes out and intraocular pressure falls.

Highyeild:

Complications include: Orbital cellulitis, Cavernous sinus thrombosis, and Meningitis or encephalitis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Steroids - not the first line of management. Option C. Use of bandage cover - not employed in the given condition. Option D. Timolol - not preferred as a first-line drug

Extraedge:

Treatment Anti-inflammatory and analgesics Broad spectrum antibiotics Evisceration

questions.text: A 16-year-old female presents with a sterile lesion over her eyelid as presented in the Image below. Histopathology shows a Lipo granulomatous chronic inflammatory Image with extracellular fat deposits surrounded by lipid-laden epithelioid cells, multinucleated giant cells, and lymphocytes. Which of the following options is not an appropriate modality for further management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oral antibiotics The given case points towards the diagnosis of a chalazion or Meibomian cyst . A chalazion is a sterile chronic granulomatous inflammatory lesion (lymphogranuloma) of the meibomian, or sometimes Zeis glands caused by retained sebaceous secretions. Histopathology shows a Lipo granulomatous chronic inflammatory picture with extracellular fat deposits surrounded by lipid-laden epithelioid cells, multinucleated giant cells, and lymphocytes.

Highyeild:

Blepharitis is commonly present; rosacea can be associated with multiple and recurrent chalazia. Oral antibiotics are required for significant bacterial infection, but not for sterile inflammation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hot compress application several times daily may aid resolution, particularly in early lesions. Option: C. Expression: Compression between two cotton-tipped applicators is sometimes effective in expressing the contents of a fresh lesion near the lid margin. Option: D. Steroid injection into or around the lesion has been reported to give similar resolution rates to incision and curettage. It may be preferred for marginal lesions or lesions close to structures such as the lacrimal punctum because of the risk of surgical damage. Reported regimens include 2-2 ml of triamcinolone acetonide aqueous suspension diluted with lidocaine to a concentration of 5 mg/ml and 0.1-0.2 ml of 40 mg/ml, injected with a 27- or 30-gauge needle. The success rate following one injection is about 80 percent. A second can be given 1-2 weeks later. Local skin depigmentation and fat atrophy are uncommon complications, which are less likely to occur by utilizing a conjunctival approach. Retinal vascular occlusion has been described as a rare complication.

Extraedge:

At least one-third resolves spontaneously so observation may be appropriate, especially if the lesion is showing signs of improvement.

questions.text: Shivamma was posted for cataract surgery. Professor asked you to determine and calculate the power of IOL to be implanted. What investigation do you perform?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Biometer The most common method of determining IOL power uses a regression formula called 'SRK (Sanders, Retzlaff, and Kraff) formula' The formula is: P-A-2.5L-0.9K, where: P is the power of IOL, A is a constant that is specific to each lens type. L is the axial length of the eyeball in mm, which is determined by A-scan ultrasonography . K is the average corneal curvature, which is determined by keratometry.

Highyeild:

Equipment for biometry A-scan ultrasonic biometer . The ultrasound machine equipped with A-scan and IOL power calculation software is called 'Biometer! Optical biometers are non-contact optical devices based on the principle of partial coherence interferometry (PCI). These are quick and more accurate devices. Commercially available optical biometers are: IOL Master Tm (Zeiss Humphrey system) and Lenstar

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Pachymetry - "A pachymetry is a simple, quick, and painless examination used to measure the thickness of the cornea " It has different applications in daily clinical practice, such as a complimentary examination in glaucoma, to determine potential refractive surgery or even to diagnose certain diseases of the cornea. Option: B. Tonometer - Tonometry is a test to measure the pressure inside your eyes . The test is used to screen for glaucoma and to measure how well glaucoma treatment is working. People over the age of 40 years, particularly African Americans, have the highest risk of developing glaucoma. Regular eye exams can help detect glaucoma early. Option D. Tomography Tonography is a clinical test of aqueous humor dynamics that was introduced by Morton Grant in 1950 Grant showed that analysis of a continuous recording from an electronic Schiotz tonometer yielded estimates of aqueous outflow and rate of aqueous flow. The principle of the test may be traced to the massage effect whereby pressure on the eye leads to a softening of the globe due to an increased outflow of aqueous humor induced by the higher pressure. Grant recorded the output of an electronic tonometer on a strip- chart recorder. Options A, B, and D are not the correct options.
